unnormalised: It's important to remember the correct usage of professional titles. For example, Dr. Sharma holds a PhD, so both Dr. and PhD are appropriate, but using both "Dr. Sharma, PhD" can be redundant. Similarly, Prof. Kumar is a Professor, but if he becomes a Head of Department (HOD), you'd address him as "HOD Kumar" or "Prof. Kumar, HOD". Avoid using "Mr. Dr. Patel", as the higher title (Dr.) supersedes the generic honorific. Keep in mind cultural nuances; in some contexts, adding "ji" to a title (e.g., "Prof. Kumar ji") shows respect.
normalised: It's important to remember the correct usage of professional titles. For example, D-r Sharma holds a P-h-D, so both D-r and P-h-D are appropriate, but using both "D-r Sharma, P-h-D" can be redundant. Similarly, P-r-o-f Kumar is a Professor, but if he becomes a Head of Department (H-O-D), you'd address him as "H-O-D Kumar" or "P-r-o-f Kumar, H-O-D". Avoid using "M-r D-r Patel", as the higher title (D-r) supersedes the generic honorific. Keep in mind cultural nuances; in some contexts, adding "ji" to a title (e.g., "P-r-o-f Kumar ji") shows respect.
